Title:
Lyomyces fissuratus and L. fumosus nov. spp.
(Hymenochaetales) from southern China
Keywords:
Schizoporaceae, Hymenochaetales, Phylogeny, Taxonomy,
Wood-inhabiting fungi, Yunnan Province
Abstract:
Two new wood-inhabiting fungal species, Lyomyces
fissuratus and L. fumosus nov. spp. are proposed based on a combination
of morphological and molecular evidence. Lyomyces fissuratus is
characterised by resupinate basidiomata with tuberculate, cracking
hymenial surface and broadly ellipsoid to subglobose, colorless,
slightly thick-walled, smooth basidiospores (46 × 3.65.3 µm). Lyomyces
fumosus is characterised by resupinate, farinaceous to pruinose
basidiomata with smooth, smoky gray hymenial surface and broad ellipsoid
to globose, colorless, slightly thick-walled basidiospores (3.86.2 ×
3.35.4 µm). Sequences of ITS and LSU nrRNA gene regions of the studied
samples were generated, and phylogenetic analyses were performed with
maximum likelihood, maximum parsimony and bayesian inference methods.
The phylogenetic analyses based on molecular data of ITS+nLSU sequences
among related genera with Lyomyces in Schizoporaceae showed that two new
species nested into Lyomyces. The further phylogenetic tree in Lyomyces
demonstrated that L. fissuratus formed a monophyletic lineage and then
grouped with a clade comprising L. mascarensis, L. cremeus, L.
microfasciculatus and L. wuliangshanensis. Lyomyces fumosus was sister
to L. fimbriatus.
